content.text: To establish a comprehensive framework that protects all students from harm, promotes wellbeing, and creates a culture of safety across all Eduversal Partner Schools.

content.title: Quick Reference for Any Staff Member Receiving a Disclosure
items: Listen calmly and do not interrupt the student.
Believe the student and thank them for speaking up.
Do not promise confidentiality; explain you must share with the DSL to keep them safe.
Report to the Designated Safeguarding Lead (DSL) immediately on the same day.
Complete the safeguarding concern form as soon as possible.
If there is immediate danger, contact emergency services and notify school leadership at once.

content.title: Policy Statement
content.text: Eduversal Partner Schools are committed to safeguarding and promoting the welfare of all children and young people. Every child has the right to protection from abuse, neglect, exploitation, and harm.

content.title: Core Commitments
items: All adults in the school community share responsibility to act on safeguarding concerns.
Prevention, early intervention, and timely response are essential.
Partnership with families strengthens child protection outcomes.
Safeguarding applies to employees, board members, contractors, volunteers, and visitors.
Continuous learning and policy improvement are mandatory.

content.title: Who Is Protected
content.text: All enrolled students are covered by this policy, with additional vigilance for vulnerable learners including students with disabilities, EAL learners, boarders, and children experiencing family instability.

content.title: Key Definitions
rows: Any individual under 18 years of age.
Actions to protect children from harm and promote safe development.
Specific response to suspected or confirmed abuse or neglect.
Acts or omissions causing physical, emotional, sexual harm, or neglect.
Designated Safeguarding Lead responsible for coordination and case management.
Behavior by an adult that does not meet referral threshold but is inconsistent with expected professional standards.

content.title: Indonesian Legal Basis
content.text: Implementation is aligned with Indonesian child protection law, digital child protection provisions, and Ministry of Education regulations on anti-violence and safe school environments.

content.title: Key Regulatory Expectations
items: Mandatory reporting of suspected abuse to relevant authorities.
Clear school code of conduct and anti-bullying procedures.
Safe environment standards, supervision controls, and prevention systems.
Cooperation with child protection, police, and social service agencies.

content.title: Primary Reporting Bodies
items: KPAI (Komisi Perlindungan Anak Indonesia)
P2TP2A local integrated service centers
Police Unit PPA (Women and Children Protection Unit)
Relevant social services and health agencies

content.text: Safeguarding accountability is distributed across governance, leadership, and all school personnel.

content.title: Board of Trustees (Eduversal Foundation)
resp: Approve and annually review safeguarding policy.
Ensure adequate resources for safer recruitment, training, and case management.
Receive annual safeguarding assurance and monitor network compliance.

content.title: Local Yayasan and General Manager
resp: Ensure local legal compliance and implementation quality.
Support high-risk case escalation, agency coordination, and governance reporting.
Ensure audits, action plans, and evidence records are maintained.

content.title: Principal
resp: Lead school safeguarding culture and operational accountability.
Ensure all staff understand reporting pathways and boundaries.
Oversee allegations against staff with HR and legal support.

content.title: DSL and Deputy DSL(s)
resp: Receive, assess, and manage all safeguarding concerns.
Maintain confidential records and referral decisions.
Coordinate support plans, external referrals, and case follow-up.
Lead training, induction controls, and annual safeguarding review.

content.title: All Staff, Volunteers, and Contractors
resp: Complete required safeguarding training and follow the code of conduct.
Report concerns immediately; do not investigate independently.
Model professional boundaries and child-centered behavior at all times.

content.title: Students and Parents
resp: Students are encouraged to report concerns through trusted adults and school systems.
Parents partner with school safeguarding plans and follow communication protocols.
Families receive policy awareness updates and referral pathway guidance.

content.text: Recruitment controls are designed to prevent unsuitable individuals from working with children.

content.title: Recruitment Process for All Staff and Volunteers
items: Use job descriptions that clearly state safeguarding responsibilities and regulated activity with children.
Require complete application history and explanation of gaps.
Screen declarations on criminal history and child-related disciplinary findings.
Use interview questions to assess values, boundaries, and disclosure response competence.
Complete at least two reference checks including child-safety suitability.
Verify identity, qualifications, right to work, and legally required background checks before start.
Do not permit unsupervised student contact until pre-employment checks are cleared.

content.title: Single Central Register (SCR) Minimum Fields
rows: Recorded with issue date and status
At least two, including safeguarding suitability

content.text: Every member of the school community must understand safeguarding risks and reporting duties.

content.title: Minimum Training Matrix
rows: Level 1 child protection training + annual refresher
Full course every 2 years; refresher yearly
Basic child protection training before regular contact

content.title: Student and Parent Awareness
items: Age-appropriate student lessons on safe relationships, reporting, and online safety.
Regular parent communication on school safeguarding expectations and referral channels.
Translated and accessible materials where required.

content.text: All staff must recognize possible indicators of abuse and respond in a calm, child-centered, and procedurally correct way.

content.title: Possible Indicators of Harm
items: Unexplained injuries or repeated injuries.
Sudden behavioral changes, withdrawal, fear, or regression.
Age-inappropriate sexualized language or behavior.
Persistent neglect indicators: poor hygiene, hunger, lack of supervision.
Frequent absenteeism, distress, or signs of coercion/exploitation.

content.title: Response Protocol
items: Listen, reassure, and avoid leading questions.
State clearly that information must be shared with safeguarding leads.
Record facts promptly using the standard concern form.
Report to DSL immediately; if unavailable, escalate to DDSL/Principal.
If emergency risk exists, contact emergency services and leadership without delay.

content.text: Low-level concerns involve adult conduct that falls below expected professional standards, even where formal abuse thresholds are not met.

content.title: Examples
items: Inappropriate personal messaging with students.
Boundary-blurring behavior or favoritism.
Dismissive or humiliating comments toward a student.
Repeated minor protocol breaches that increase safeguarding risk.

content.title: Management
items: Report and record through the low-level concern form and log.
Review patterns over time and escalate where risk accumulates.
Provide proportionate management action: supervision, coaching, warning, or formal process.

content.text: Safeguarding records must be factual, timely, secure, and accessible only to authorized personnel.

content.title: Record-Keeping Standards
items: Record all concerns, decisions, actions, referrals, and outcomes.
Use dated and signed standardized forms with objective language.
Store in secure physical or encrypted digital safeguarding systems.
Keep safeguarding files separate from academic records.
Retain records according to legal and policy timelines, and transfer securely when required.

subsections.title: Code of Conduct and Professional Boundaries

content.text: Clear professional boundaries protect children and staff.

content.title: All Staff Must
items: Treat students with respect, fairness, and dignity.
Use appropriate language and behavior at all times.
Maintain physical and emotional boundaries.
Use only approved communication channels with students.
Avoid one-to-one unsupervised situations where risk is increased.
Report boundary breaches immediately.

content.text: Any allegation that an adult has harmed a child, may pose risk, or may be unsuitable to work with children requires immediate and formal handling.

content.title: Immediate Actions
items: Report allegation immediately to Principal (or to higher authority if Principal/GM is implicated).
Implement immediate risk controls to protect students while preserving fairness and due process.
Open formal investigation pathway with HR/legal and, where required, external authorities.
Maintain strict confidentiality and documentation discipline.
Communicate outcomes and follow-up controls appropriately.

content.text: Context-specific controls are required for boarding, trips, online environments, peer abuse, and mental health concerns.

items: Boarding schools (if applicable)
School trips and off-site activities
Online safety and digital safeguarding
Peer-on-peer abuse
Mental health and wellbeing

content.title: Core Controls
items: Gender-appropriate supervision and clear staffing ratios.
Documented nighttime supervision and emergency contact systems.
Secure access control and student movement management.
Privacy and dignity protections in residential facilities.
Specialized safeguarding training for boarding personnel.

content.title: Trip Safeguarding Requirements
items: Complete and approve safeguarding risk assessment before departure.
Set supervision ratios appropriate to age, context, and student needs.
Ensure gender balance in staffing for mixed groups.
Carry confidential medical/safeguarding information securely.
Use clear communication, check-in, and lost-student procedures.
Record and report any safeguarding incident during or after trip.

content.title: Priority Digital Risks
items: Cyberbullying and online harassment.
Online grooming and exploitation.
Exposure to harmful or age-inappropriate content.
Sexting and image-based abuse.
Privacy breaches, identity misuse, and unsafe data sharing.

content.title: School Measures
items: Filtered and monitored internet access.
Annual Acceptable Use Policy sign-off for students and staff.
Device management controls on school systems.
Age-appropriate digital citizenship curriculum.
Clear reporting and response routes for online incidents.

content.text: Peer abuse includes physical, emotional, sexual, discriminatory, and online harm between students and is treated as a safeguarding issue.

content.title: Response Principles
items: Zero tolerance for abuse and clear behavior expectations.
Immediate victim safety and support planning.
Prompt investigation and proportionate consequences.
Restorative and educational interventions where appropriate.
Parent engagement and monitoring of both victim and perpetrator risk.

content.text: Serious mental health concerns such as self-harm or suicidal ideation are safeguarding concerns requiring immediate DSL involvement.

content.title: Immediate Response to High Risk
items: Do not leave the student alone.
Contact DSL and school leadership immediately.
Notify parent/guardian unless doing so increases risk.
Seek urgent medical or psychiatric support when indicated.
Develop and monitor an individual safety and support plan.

content.text: Staff must be able to report safeguarding failures, misconduct, or cover-ups without fear of retaliation.

content.title: Reporting Escalation Path
items: Report to GM where concern involves DSL or staff-level response failures.
Escalate to Chief of Academics for concerns about school leadership.
Escalate to Board Chair for network-level or senior leadership concerns.
Report externally to authorities when internal channels are unsafe or ineffective.

content.title: Protections
items: No retaliation for good-faith reporting.
Confidential handling and fair process.
Action against malicious or knowingly false reporting.

content.text: Complex or high-risk cases require coordinated response with child protection, police, health, and social service agencies.

content.title: External Agency Collaboration
rows: Child protection guidance, services, legal and psychosocial support
Investigation of criminal abuse and protection actions
Medical assessment, emergency care, psychiatric intervention
Family welfare interventions and neglect support
Specialized counseling, advocacy, and protection programs

content.title: Operational Expectations
items: Maintain updated referral contacts and documented pathways.
Use MOUs where appropriate for role clarity and response speed.
Track referrals, outcomes, and case closure evidence.

content.text: Each school completes an annual safeguarding audit to review policy compliance, response quality, and continuous improvement priorities.

content.title: Audit Scope
items: Policy currency and legal alignment.
Training completion and effectiveness by role.
Incident trend and response-time analysis.
Safer recruitment and SCR completeness.
Student/parent voice and confidence in reporting.
Action plan with deadlines, owners, and measurable outcomes.

content.title: Annual Reporting
items: Submit safeguarding report to governance bodies.
Escalate high-risk systemic gaps immediately.
Use findings to set next-year safeguarding priorities.

content.title: Policy and Governance Evidence
items: Current safeguarding policy and annual review log.
Signed staff code of conduct records.
Whistleblowing, anti-bullying, and online safety policies.
Board and leadership safeguarding minutes and reports.

content.title: Recruitment, Training, and Incident Evidence
items: Single Central Register with checks and verification dates.
Training records with completion and expiry tracking by role.
Concern forms, DSL logs, referral records, and case outcomes.
Trip risk assessments, safety plans, and incident follow-up records.

categories.title: Indonesian Legal Requirements
items: Law No. 35/2014 on Child Protection: mandatory reporting, child safety duties, anti-violence measures.
Law No. 17/2016 and digital protection obligations: online safety controls and prevention actions.
Ministry regulations on child-friendly schools and school safety implementation.

categories.title: CIS Standards
items: Health and Safety expectations for safeguarding policy, training, and safer recruitment.
School culture standards for respectful, safe, and inclusive environments.
Operational systems standards for documentation and accountability.

categories.title: WASC Categories
items: Category E: student personal and academic growth supported by safe culture and intervention systems.
Policies and practices requiring equitable protection and timely support for at-risk students.

categories.title: Cambridge and International Child Rights
items: Cambridge center expectations for child protection and student welfare safeguards.
UN Convention on the Rights of the Child principles: best interests, protection, participation, and dignity.

content.title: Policy Maintenance Cycle
items: Annual review at the end of each academic year based on audit outcomes.
Mid-year check in January for urgent risks or regulatory changes.
Immediate emergency update after serious incidents or legal changes.
Approval pathway: DSL and school leadership, then governance review for major revisions.
Communicate updates to staff, students, and parents with implementation guidance.

content.title: Network and External Emergency Contacts
rows: Use latest local/national hotline and reporting channels

subsections.title: Conclusion: Commitment to Every Child's Safety

content.text: Safeguarding is a daily culture, not a compliance checklist. Eduversal Partner Schools commit to child-centered practice, professional accountability, early intervention, and continuous improvement so that every child is safe, heard, respected, and able to thrive.
